metadata.title: The effect of nano-MgO on the setting time, autogenous shrinkage, microstructure and mechanical properties of high performance cement paste and mortar

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
The effect of nano-MgO on the setting time, autogenous shrinkage, microstructure and mechanical properties of high performance cement paste and mortar
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2017.08.168 0950-0618/ 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: rizapolat@atauni.edu.tr, rizapolat@gmail.com (R. Polat).
Rıza Polat a,⇑, Ramazan Demirboğa b, Fatma Karagöl a aDepartment of Civil Engineering, Engineering Faculty, Atatürk University, 25240 Erzurum, Turkey bCollege of Engineering, Department of Architectural Engineering, Alfaisal University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
h i g h l i g h t s
The nano-MgO improves the properties of the cementitious materials over time. The nano-MgO increases the hydration heat and compressive strength of mortar. The autogenous shrinkage decreases with the increasing of nano-MgO content. The nano-MgO developments the microstructure of the mortar.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 28 April 2017 Received in revised form 19 August 2017 Accepted 30 August 2017
Keywords: Nano-MgO Autogenous shrinkage Compressive strength Setting time Heat of hydration
a b s t r a c t
Many studies have targeted the application of micro-size MgO to reduce autogenous shrinkage in cement based materials. However, there is little knowledge the effect of nano-MgO on the mechanical, durability and microstructure properties of high-performance cement-based materials. In this paper, the properties of cement pastes and mortars with nano-MgO were experimentally investigated. 2.5%, 5.0% and 7.5% nano-MgO by weight of binder were used in mortar and paste mixtures. While the setting time and the volumetric autogenous shrinkage tests were carried out in paste mixtures, the heat of hydration, 7 and 28 days compressive strength, ultrasonic pulse velocity (UPV) and 28 days linear autogenous shrinkage test were carried out in mortar mixtures. In addition, Scanning Electron Microscopic (SEM) observations were also made to evaluate the effect of nano-MgO on microstructure. It was concluded that nano-MgO had a significant effect on the fresh and hardened properties of cement pastes and mortars. Generally, nano-MgO increased the compressive strength (about up to 8%). Nano-MgO decreased autogenous shrinkage and setting time decreased with an increased in use of nano-MgO. The final hydration heat of the control mixtures and the nano-MgO mixtures are almost the same. Nano-MgO can be used as an expanding additive.
2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The use of nanomaterials in cement composites as the most used building material in the world has been investigated over the past few years. The physical and mechanic behavior of cement composites depends on the properties of components and physical and chemical changes that occur at the micro and nano level. CSH gel formed as a result of reactions of cement with water is a natural nanostructure material. Accordingly, nanotechnology can modify the molecular structure improving the concrete’s bulk properties
and allows the development of inexpensive, high-strength and durable products of cement-based materials [1,2]. In general, it is now known that nanomaterials improve the fundamental properties of cement composites such as strength, durability, physical, microstructure [3–7].
Nanoparticles, particles of less than 100 nm in diameter, generally shows the properties of electrical, physical, mechanic or chemical that are entirely dissimilar from those showed by the same products with larger dimensions. Nanomaterials with different chemical properties have been used in the production of cement paste and mortar and improved the mechanical, physical, chemical and durability properties of cement composites. The inclusion of nanoparticles into the cementitious materials may be
as spherical materials (e.g., nano-SiO2, nano-Cu2O3, nano-TiO2, nano-Al2O3, nano-CaCO3, nano-Fe2O3, nano-CuO, nano-Fe3O4, nano-ZnO2, nano-ZrO2, nano-ZnO etc.) or as nanotubes or fibers (e.g., carbon nanotubes and carbon nanofibers, respectively) or as nano-clay. In the relevant literature, many researchers have shown that even at small dosages, nano-SiO2 can develop the mechanical properties of cement composites [2,8–10] and the microstructure becomes more compact [2,11,12]. Morsy et al. [1] showed that the use of single and combination of nano metakaolin and carbon nanotubes increases the compressive strength compared to control mix. Fan et al. [13] stated that a suitable calcined nano-kaolinite clay addition amends the strength of cement based mortar exposed to acid. In the separate study, Farzadnia et al. [14] showed that incorporation of nano-clay in mortars improved the compressive strength by up to 24% in samples with 3% nano-clay. Nano-clay particles better the properties of cement composites showing a pozzolanic reaction with cement and micro-filling effect [15,16]. Noorvand et al. [17] and Nazari and Riahi [18] found that there have been a few studies regarding the functionality of nano-TiO2 on hardened cement composites. Generally, one of the broadlystudied functions of nanoparticles is their nucleation effect in the cement paste [19]. Farzadnia et al. [20] and Farzadnia et al. [21] showed that nano-titania and nano-alumina used in mortar mixtures increased mechanic properties and energy absorption of mortars. Nano-CaCO3 particles create a suitable environment for nucleation of hydration products and eventually improve hydration reactions and besides treat as nano-fillers thereby developing the mechanical properties of cement composites [22–24]. Aside from these, Nazari and Riahi [25] and Nazari and Riahi [26] experimentally showed that nano-ZnO2 and nano-TiO2 powders improved the mechanical and physical properties of the concrete [27]. There are much more studies on nanomaterials [28,29].
On the other hand, the application of high-performance cement composites is continually augmenting due to its superior durability, mechanical, physical and other properties according to normal cement based composites [30]. However, high-performance cement composites produced with tremendously low w/c ratios is vulnerable autogenous shrinkage and even failure (cracks) [31]. These cracks deteriorate the concrete properties and a lot of research has been done to reduce them [32]. These are internal curing with lightweight aggregates [31,33–37], fibers [38–42], recycle aggregate [43] and expansive reactions [44]. In their studies, the autogenous shrinkage reduced, but the strengths also simultaneously reduction. Cracks in high-performance cement composites occur the formation of nano-micro scales and have a high impact on the durability of high-performance cement composites and these could be controlled by incorporating nanoscale materials [45].
MgO-based expansive additives for the shrinkage reduction was discovered and used for years. MgO reacts with water, and the hydration reaction produces Mg(OH)2. Because of the difference in density between MgO (3.58 g/cm3) and Mg(OH)2 (2.36 g/cm3), when MgO converts to Mg(OH)2, the volume more than doubles. Many studies have been investigated the hydration and expansion of light and dead-burnt MgO [46–52]. As a result, micron-sized MgO generally decreases the autogenous shrinkage but, on the other hand, also decreases the strengths. The particle diameter and calcining temperature influenced the degree of hydration of the MgO expansive agent. Low calcining temperature and smaller particle diameter increased the rate of hydration of MgO expansive agent. The expansion of cement paste decreased with an increase in the calcining temperature of MgO expansive agent. The expansion time was prolonged and it occurred in a later period when the holding time was prolonged. The best calcining system was treatment at 1000 C for 1 h with the particle diameter of
45–150 lm [53]. Therefore, both the mechanical and durability properties of nano-MgO high-performance cement composites should be carefully examined.
The properties of mortars containing nano-MgO were experimentally studied by Moradpour et al. [54], Polat et al. [55], Ye et al. [56], Kahidan [57] and Hou et al. [58]. Moradpour et al. [54] stated that the strengths increased in mixtures containing nano-MgO particle, nano-MgO behaved as a filler to enhance cement composites internal structure. Ye et al. [56] expressed that nano-MgO used in cementitious materials does not damage the mechanical properties and increases the strength in later age at water curing and that nano-MgO may use as the expansive agent for cement materials. Polat et al. [55] experimentally showed that reduction in autogenous shrinkage due to nano-MgO was higher than that of MgO for same mixture ratios. Kahidan [57] stated the hydration rate of nano-MgO cured as standard was low. Gao et al. [59] investigated the effect of nano-MgO for clay and used different nano-MgO contents (0%, 1%, 2%, 3%, 4%, 5%, 6%) in their study and stated that nano-MgO improved the strength and stability of the clay increasing the cementation and pore filling. Yuan et al. [60] investigated the effect of using nano-MgO in the properties of thermal energy storage materials produced with aluminate cement. The pressure strength of the samples produced with 1% nano-MgO was found to be 30.5% higher than the samples produced with pure cement. Hou et al. [58] investigated the effects of the hydration reactivity of ultrafine MgO on cementitious materials and stated that the initial and final setting times are shortened with using ultrafine MgO, the compressive strengths of samples with ultrafine MgO decreased at the later ages while the compressive strength of samples with ultrafine MgO increased at early ages and the effects of MgO on cement hydration varied considerably with water binder ratio.
As seen in the literature, Moradpour et al. [54] and Ye et al. [56] studied the strength of mortars which water/binder ratio is 0.50 and the strengths also increased for with small amounts of nanoMgO. But, MgO based expansive additives are used for high strength (performance) mortar/concretes that occurred the micro-nano cracks and produced with low water/binder ratio (below than 0.42). Mo et al. [50] expressed that MgO based additives may be more suitable for concrete which has low permeability and insufficiency the external water curing. Thus, it is important the examination of the effect of nano-MgO in cement composites with low water/binder ratio. It is also necessary to investigate the effect of nano-MgO on the properties of the cementitious materials other than the strength and expansion properties.
This research aimed to investigate the performance of nanoMgO on the properties of high-performance cement composites in terms of microstructure, durability and mechanical properties. For this purpose, the effect of nano-MgO as an additive on the durability and mechanical properties of high strength mortars and pastes was investigated. 2.5%, 5.0% and 7.5% nano-MgO as cement replacement were added to high strength mortars and pastes. Compressive strength, linear autogenous shrinkage, UPV, SEM for mortar mixtures and the setting time and volumetric autogenous shrinkage for paste mixtures were also obtained.
2. Experimental work
2.1. Materials
Ordinary Portland cement (PC) (type I – 42.5 MPa) in compliance with ASTM C150/C150M [61], 7% silica fume (SF) a replacement with cement, and natural river sand that has the maximum particle size of 4 mm according to ASTM C33/C33M [62] were used. Table 1 shows the properties of Portland cement and silica fume. Water to binder ratio of 0.30 and 0.5% for paste mixtures and 2% for mortar mixtures naphthalene sulfonate base superplasticizer (SP) were applied. The
nano-MgO ratio was 0%, 2.5%, 5.0%, and 7.5% of the binder. The properties and XRD results of the nano-MgO are given in Table 2 and in Fig. 1, respectively. The wideness of XRD peak of nano-MgO demonstrates the nanocrystalline of the particles and three peaks of XRD match with pure magnesia [56,63]. The aggregates having two different grain diameters (0–2 and 2–4 mm) were used (in all mixtures, 70% of the aggregate mix was set to granulometry so as to pass through the 2 mm sieve). The specific gravities of 0–2 and 2–4 mm were 2.56 and 2.60, respectively.
2.2. Paste and mortar preparation
The pastes and mortars were mixed according to ASTM C 305 [64]. The binder to water ratio of cement pastes is 1:0.30. Nano-MgO and powder materials (cement and silica fume) were initially dry mixed for 7 min to disperse nanoparticles. Then, the water and superplasticizer was added and was mixed for 5 min. The paste mix proportions are given in Table 3.
The binder to sand ratio and water to binder ratio of mortars are 1:2.75 and of 0.30, respectively. Four groups of samples containing 0, 2.5%, 5.0% and 7.5% nanoMgO in 5 cm 5 cm 5 cm cubes to test compressive strength and UPV and 10 cm 10 cm 40 cm rectangles to test linear autogenous shrinkage were cast. The samples for the compressive strength were demolded and cured in lime saturated water according to ASTM C 511 [65] and the specimens for autogenous shrinkage were stored at a room temperature of 20 C and a relative humidity of
Fig. 1. XRD plot of the p
65%. Mix proportions of mortars are given in Table 4. Mixtures for the heat of hydration were mixed according to TS EN 196-9 [66] and mix proportions of mortar are given in Table 5.
2.3. Testing
The initial and the final setting time were made with the needle of Vicat apparatus according to ASTM C191 [67].
Measurements of volumetric autogenous strain were performed by monitoring the weight of cement paste samples contained in elastic membranes and immersed in buoyancy liquid, (distilled water). The experiments were done by volumetric in a climate room at 23 ± 0.2 C; details of the method were specified in the literature [68]. The immersed weight of the paste sample was measured and recorded automatically every 1 min by controlling software from initial setting time after casting up to about 48 h [55,69,70]
The heat of hydration for mortars containing nano-MgO was determined with the Langavant calorimeter defined according to TS EN 196-9 [66]. The semiadiabatic method is based on determining the amount of heat generated by the temperature rise formed reactions between cement and water by the placement of the new (immediate) mortar sample. The test was carried out in a perfectly climatized room at 20 ± 2 C. The measurements were made over 2 days (48 h).
The UPV and the compressive strength tests of mortars were conducted to according to ASTM C 597 [71] and ASTM C 109/C109M [72], respectively. 50 50 50 mm3 cube samples were used in the compression test with a loading rate of 3.16 kg/cm2/s.
The linear autogenous shrinkage and the internal temperature of samples were measured for 28 days after the initial setting time by a strain gauge (with a length of 10 cm) and a thermocouple embedded in the specimen (Fig. 2) [36,55].
To determine the formed phase composition in mortar samples, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were used. A representative of each sample was obtained at 28 days for microstructural tests.
repared nano-MgO.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Setting time
sections.text:
The results of the initial setting, final setting and setting time (the duration between final and initial setting times) are shown in Fig. 3. The mean setting times in nano-MgO mixtures were generally shorter than in C. The incorporation of 5.0% and %7.5 nanoMgO reduced the setting times of paste by 20 min and 10 min, respectively. But the incorporation of 2.5% nano-MgO negligible increased the setting time of paste by 4 min. The first of probable causes is that nano-MgO particles have larger surface area and demand a higher water and hence, the setting time is shortened. The second cause is that viscosity increases due to rapid depletion of the mixture water and solidification started earlier [73]. Many researchers have reported that the setting time is reduced by increasing the content of nano-SiO2 in cement-based materials [74–76] and shorter for the samples with higher nano-TiO2 contents [73]. On the other hand, slight increases of the initial and final setting times were observed for the pastes with nano-MgO. The initial and final setting times for NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 were 281, 310, 315 min and 375, 380, 385 min, respectively. The addition of nano-MgO particles significantly affects the initial setting time and postpones it for about 10–15 min. Mg(OH)2 forms in
the presence of water (MgO + H2O?Mg(OH)2). Mg(OH)2 crystals are slowing down the hydration progress by encircling the cement particles. Kahidan [57] stated according to XRD results that the hydration of standard cured samples containing nano-MgO is low. Zheng et al. [52] expressed that the addition of MgO retards the initial hydration of cement and increases the initial and final setting time of cement. Therefore, the hydration slows and the internal temperature of cement paste is low when compared to the control samples. Eventually, by reducing the size of the material, the initial setting time has been delayed, but the setting time is reduced [52]. MgO increases the initial and final setting times of cement, but nano-MgO is less effective on the extension of setting times of cement than MgO due to its small particle size and high surface area [77].

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Volumetric autogenous shrinkage
sections.text:
The volumetric deformation of cement-based materials mainly depends on the hydration process of cementitious materials and the composition of hydration products. The volumetric autogenous deformation is usually known as the important factor causing to early age cracking and used to measure the change in external volume due to chemical shrinkage in very early ages (2–3 days), just after initial setting.
Fig. 4 shows the results of the volumetric autogenous shrinkage of cement pastes containing MgO and control paste as a function of age up to 48 h. It has not been found a study about the volumetric shrinkage of the nano-MgO mixture in the literature. But, some researchers used MgO with the larger size for the same purpose and stated that MgO decreased autogenous shrinkage [46–52]. According to Fig. 4, after initial setting times, there was the volumetric shrinkage in all the mixtures and the values of C, NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 after 48 h are 0.91%, 0.87%, 0.75% and 0.68%, respectively. The values of shrinkage decreased with increased the nano-MgO content. Nano-MgO shows the slow reaction with water [50,55] and has the very fine particle size and high surface area [55]. These properties increase its reaction
and expansion and also makes more uniform expansion takes place in the cement paste. When the control sample is compared with MgO 7.5, it is seen from Fig. 4 that the difference between the shrinkage values at 48 h is larger than the values at early ages. Hence, MgO with nano-scale decreases the early age volumetric shrinkage.
The volumetric autogenous shrinkage is the change in external volume due to chemical shrinkage in very early ages and the chemical shrinkage also is described as the absolute-internal volume change of cement paste that results from the hydration reaction of cement-based materials [78]. In this study, the chemical shrinkage declined with the decreasing the amount of cement because of the use of nano-MgO instead of cement, and thus, the volumetric shrinkage is also reduced. In addition, as a result of the reaction between nano-MgO and water, the volume expansion (118%) has occurred due to the formation of Mg(OH)2 and as a result it restrained the effect of chemical shrinkage.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Hydration heat
sections.text:
The Langavant calorimeter is used to calculate and measure the hydration heat of the cement bymeasuring the temperature change in the cement mortars (totally 1575 ± 1 g = standard sand (1080 g) + binder (360 g) + water (180 g)) placed in the semi-adiabatic
calorimeter. The hydration heat curves of C, NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 mixtures are presented in Fig. 5. The first heat evolution during mixing and placing (the possibility, 6 min) cannot be saved because of the mortar mixtures prepared outside the calorimeter. As shown in Fig. 5, the heat of hydration increased for all the mixtures at an early age (in particular, for the first 16 h) and very rapid between 4 and 16 h. The main increment occurred earlier for all the samples containing nano-MgO in comparisonwith the C.
The addition of the nano-MgO substantially increased the angles of the heat increment on the curve. The increase of nanoMgO dosage from 2.5% to 5.0% enhanced these effects, but the totally heat released in 48 h for C, NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 were 306.54 J/g, 303.72 J/g, 311.57 J/g and 313.59 J/g. NMgO2.5 decreased by 0.9% the heat of hydration, but NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 increased by 1.6% and 2.3% according to C samples. The hydration heat in the samples containing nano-MgO was slightly higher for the duration between 4 and 28 h than in the later ages when compared to C samples. Zheng et al. [52] explained that at age 2 days, the hydration heat for pure MgO is 65.29 Cal/g, for the cement containing 4% MgO is 45.03 Cal/g, and for Portland cement is 43.47 Cal/g, also, expressed that the addition of MgO retards the initial hydration of cement. On the other hand, the hydration development of MgO expansive additive was affected by its particle size and the specific surface area of MgO expansion
additive. While the particle size of MgO expansive additive declines, the higher hydration reaction rate occurs at early ages [79]. For this reason, in this study, since MgO is in nano-size, the reaction with water is faster and more heat reveals in early ages. Contrary to this previous finding, the addition of nano-MgO in high strength mortar results in a slightly higher hydration heat with respect to that of the control mixture at early ages since the hydration heat of pure MgO is higher than the displaced cement (CaO-SiO, CaO-Al2O3, Fe2O3. . .). Several researchers showed that ultra-fine particles accelerate the hydration of cement [80,81]. Namely, the smaller particle size and larger surface area of nanoMgO enhances the dissolution rate of cement compounds in the early stage of cement hydration [82]. The final hydration heat of the control mixtures and the nano-MgO mixtures are almost the same.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Compressive strength
sections.text:
Fig. 6 shows the strengths of mortars at 7 and 28 days. At the age of 7 days, the compressive strengths decreased with the use of nano-MgO increasing but the strengths slightly increased with the increase of nano-MgO dosage [56]. The compressive strengths for C, NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 were 71.0 MPa, 63.3 MPa, 64.2 MPa and 66.9 MPa, respectively. At the age of 28 days, the
compressive strengths for C, NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 were 74.7 MPa, 75.6 MPa, 73.3 MPa and 80.9 MPa, respectively. The standard compressive strengths of mixtures containing 2.5%, 5.0% and 7.5% nano-MgO changed about 1.10%, 1.9% and 8.2% according to C. Generally, it can be said that the addition of nano-MgO increases 28-day compressive strength [56,58]. According to Hou et al. [58], the compressive strengths of the w/b = 0.60 mortars increased with increasing amounts of ultrafine MgO until 28 day but decreased due to the seeding and coating effects on the surfaces of cement particles, at 90 and 180 days due. This increase in the compressive strength of mortar containing ultrafine MgO at early ages could be due to its high activity and the seeding effect [58].
As shown in Fig. 7, the increase in compressive strength between 7 and 28 days for C, NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 were 5.2%, 19.3%, 14.3% and 20.9%, respectively, and nano-MgO improves the internal structure of the concrete over time.
In the literature, several researchers have shown that even at small dosages, nanomaterials can develop some properties of cementitious materials and the microstructure becomes more compact [1,2,8–12,14–16,20,21,25,26,83]. Choi et al. [46] showed that hydration reaction of MgO occurs at a slower rate until 28 days, then the hydration rate increases. The Mg(OH)2 crystals
gO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 samples.
formed as a result of chemical reaction with water of nano-MgO accrete with curing time and these crystals grow up over time and filled the pores of cement paste and made the structure denser with time. For this reason, the compressive strength of the MgO mortar remained lower at early ages, compared to that of control concrete, but a higher compressive strength was observed at later ages. Ye et al. [56] investigated the strength, soundness and expansion of cement paste and mortars containing nano-MgO and they stated that the mechanic properties of cement materials developed with the presence and increasing content of nano-MgO. Moradpour et al. [54] expressed that nano-MgO behaves as a filler and improves the microstructure and strength of cement materials.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. UPV
sections.text:
UPV test can be used for evaluation about internal cracks, porosity and microstructure of cement-based materials [84,85]. This test fundamentally includes the measurement of electronic wave velocity through cement materials [86].
UPV tests were performed on C, NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 specimens at 7 and 28 days and the results were presented in Fig. 8. Each value is the average of three measurements and normalized UPV values according to C. When it was accepted that UPV values of C were 100% at 7 days, UPV values of NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 were 99.67%, 99.69% and 99.59%, respectively. UPV values decreased with the using nano-MgO according
to the control mixtures at 7 days. However, with increasing of containing nano-MgO, it was no significant change in UPV values. UPV values of NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 changed by 0.60%, 1.66% and 0.26% according to C at 28 days, respectively. As shown in Fig. 8, the increase in the UPV values between 7 and 28 days for C, NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 were 1.70%, 1.40%, 0.30% and 2.40%, respectively.
The UPV measurements generally confirm the information obtained from the compressive strengths. Since UPV is directly related to material density and cement-aggregate + cementcement interfaces, it increases as porosity decreases [87]. As a result, NMgO7.5 improved decreasing the cracks the internal structure of the mortar over time and furthermore, Moradpour et al. [54] stated that in cement-based materials containing MgO, Mg (OH)2, which results from the reaction of MgO with water, has a larger volume and better filler effect than the other nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Linear autogenous shrinkage
sections.text:
Fig. 9 shows the autogenous shrinkage of nano-MgO mixes. The autogenous shrinkage was measured from initial setting time to 28 days (as a function of age). Within the first week of hydration, while the expansion of the MgO samples increased, the autogenous shrinkage of the control samples increased. When the results of 14 and 28 days of autogenous shrinkage were examined, it can be seen from Fig. 9 that after about 20 days, NMgO7.5 mortar sample
gO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 samples.
return to its original length and after that, it starts to shrink and at a very low rate and the other mixtures continued to shrink. At the ages of 7 and 28 days, the autogenous shrinkage of the control sample (C) reached 96.86 and 292.62 me, respectively; the autogenous shrinkage of NMgO2.5 reached 29, 66 (expansive) and 127.08 me, respectively; the autogenous shrinkage of NMgO5.0 reached 31.33 (expansive) and 125.00 me, respectively; and the autogenous shrinkage of NMgO7.5 reached 69, 32 (expansive) and 62.00 me, respectively. At the ages of 28 days, nano-MgO reduced the autogenous shrinkage by 56, 57 and 78 percent for NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 as compared to that of C’s, respectively. The reductions in the autogenous shrinkage increased by increasing the nano-MgO content [55]. When the results of 7 days of shrinkage are examined, as the nano-MgO is an expansive admixture, the expansion of mortars gradually increased with the increasing of nano-MgO in the mixes [56]. The expansion is related to nano-MgO with high activity because this property generates faster and greater expansion in concrete at the early age [79,88]. As a result of these expansion, it can be said that nano-MgO is a good candidate for compensation of early-age shrinkage [58]. This situation is in contrast to the expansion properties of coarse-size MgO which reacts at later ages-expansion. This division between two materials may be due to the differences in their reaction characteristics [58].
As shown in Fig. 9, the change in autogenous shrinkage between 7 and 28 days for C, NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5 were 195.76me ( 96.86? 292.62), 156.7me (29.66? 127.08),
156.3me (31.33? 125.00) and 131.32me (69.32? 62.00), respectively. The autogenous shrinkage change is 33% for nanoMgO 75 as compared to the control samples. These results show that over time nano-MgO improves the microstructure preventing shrinkage and therefore cracks. The reason why the mortar compressive strengths improve over time is that the internal structure is improved. Consequently, the ratio of nano-MgO added in normal cement is up to 7.5% [56]. Even though MgO in nanometer size reacts faster than micrometer size, Ye et al. [56] stated when nano-MgO is used in cement-based mortars, there is a slight amount of nano-MgO even in 360 days and it shows a slow reaction. According to the results of Ye et al. [56], nano-MgO will also reduce the autogenous shrinkage in later ages.

sections.heading: 3.2.5. SEM analysis
sections.text:
SEM images were carried out to study the effect of nano-MgO on the microstructure of mortars at 28 days (Figs. 10–12). The dense structure of mortars is also clearly shown because of high strength mortars in Figs. 10–12. Fig. 10 presents the microstructure of cement paste with nano-MgO of 2.5% at 28 days of age. The addition of nano-MgO improved the microstructure of mortars but as shown Fig. 10 that shrinkage cracks occurred and this ratio of nano-MgO is not enough. When examined Fig. 11, it was observed that NMgO5.0 also increased the density of mortar. Also, expansion of nano-MgO hence enhances filling effect in capillary pores. The larger pores in mortar did not occur, and the cracks decreased, at 28 days and NMgO5.0 enhanced a uniform and solid microstruc-
ture. In Fig. 12, even at a magnification of 1000x, NMgO7.5 samples have better internal structure compared to other ratios. Ye et al. [56] indicated that excessive amounts of MgO in cementitious mortars can cause excessive expansion and cracks. But, MgO with nano-size has different effect larger size MgO. Coarse MgO particles locally cause more expansion than fine ones. In terms of volume stability, mechanical strength, and durability, the performance of MgO in cement composites is closely related to its raw materials, mix proportion, curing conditions as well as the restraint condition. Appropriate expansion contributes to the densification of cement composites and is beneficial to the performance of cement composites whilst excessive expansion may destroy the microstructure of concrete and therefore cause deterioration on the performance of concrete. On the other hand, the magnesium hydroxide resulting from the hydration of nano-MgO has a larger volume and a better filling effect in comparison with other nanoparticles and magnesium silicate formation, the other product resulting from the hydration of MgO, may be another reason for changing the mechanical properties of mortars. Moradpour et al. [54] stated that nano-MgO particles affected the microstructure
of the hardened pastes and had a denser matrix in comparison to plain composite due to the filling effect and the expansion effect of Mg(OH)2. Sherir et al. [89] stated that the MgO-based expansive additive to produce cohesive cement-based products such as magnesium silicate hydrates at later ages may supplement the formation of C-S-H products at early ages and contribute to more intensification of microstructure. Hou et al. [58] was observed by SEM the internal structure of the cement pastes with 3% ultrafine MgO at ages 7, 90 and 180 days and stated that the ultrafine MgO improved the internal structure in parallel with the mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The following conclusions can be drawn from this study:
– The incorporation of 5.0% and %7.5 nano-MgO reduced the setting time of paste by 20 min and 10 min, respectively. – The values of shrinkage decreased by increasing the nano-MgO content.
– The heat of hydration increased for all the mixtures at an early age (in particular, for the first 16 h) and very rapid between 4 and 16 h. The main increment occurred earlier for all the samples containing nano-MgO in comparison with the C. – The standard compressive strength of mixtures containing 2.5%, 5.0% and 7.5% nano-MgO changed about 1.10%, 1.9% and 8.2% according to C. Generally, it can be said that the addition of nano-MgO increases 28-day compressive strength. – Nano-MgO improves the internal structure of the cementitious materials over time. – Nano-MgO reduced the linear autogenous shrinkage by 53, 56 and 80 percent for NMgO2.5, NMgO5.0 and NMgO7.5, respectively, and nano-MgO was able to be used as the expansive agent.
As a general conclusion, nano-MgO improves the compressive strength and reduces autogenous shrinkage in early and older ages.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This research was supported by the research project ‘‘Effects of nano materials on the autogenous shrinkage of high strength concretes” (BAP Code: 2012/441) from the Atatürk University, Scientific Research Projects (BAP) Program in Erzurum, Turkey.

metadata.abstractText: Many studies have targeted the application of micro-size MgO to reduce autogenous shrinkage in cement based materials. However, there is little knowledge the effect of nano-MgO on the mechanical, durability and microstructure properties of high-performance cement-based materials. In this paper, the properties of cement pastes and mortars with nano-MgO were experimentally investigated. 2.5%, 5.0% and 7.5% nano-MgO by weight of binder were used in mortar and paste mixtures. While the setting time and the volumetric autogenous shrinkage tests were carried out in paste mixtures, the heat of hydration, 7 and 28 days compressive strength, ultrasonic pulse velocity (UPV) and 28 days linear autogenous shrinkage test were carried out in mortar mixtures. In addition, Scanning Electron Microscopic (SEM) observations were also made to evaluate the effect of nano-MgO on microstructure. It was concluded that nano-MgO had a significant effect on the fresh and hardened properties of cement pastes and mortars. Generally, nano-MgO increased the compressive strength (about up to 8%). Nano-MgO decreased autogenous shrinkage and setting time decreased with an increased in use of nano-MgO. The final hydration heat of the control mixtures and the nano-MgO mixtures are almost the same. Nano-MgO can be used as an expanding additive. 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
